title: Progressive Limb Weakness in a Middle-Aged Man: A Case of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
clinical_history: Mr. Jason Turner is a 52-year-old male accountant who presented to the neurology clinic with complaints of progressive weakness in his left hand and forearm over the last 6 months. He reports difficulty gripping objects, frequent muscle cramping, and has noticed muscle twitching (fasciculations) in his upper limbs, primarily affecting the left side. Over the past 2 months, he has developed similar symptoms in the right hand and mild difficulty with walking due to weakness in his right ankle. He denies any sensory loss. Jason has lost approximately 5 kg unintentionally over the last three months and reports mild slurred speech developing in the past few weeks. Family has noticed that he is more fatigued in the evenings and has difficulty holding utensils at dinner. There is no family history of neuromuscular disorder.

nprs.affected_area: left forearm and hand flexor and extensor muscles (primary complaint: cramping and aching pain)
right ankle dorsiflexors and hand muscles (secondary complaint: mild aching, stiffness)

aggrevating_factors: Prolonged or repetitive use of affected limbs, fatigue, cold weather increases cramping and fasciculations, late evening activities.
picture: [Insert a clinical diagram showing muscle wasting of the left hand and forearm, fasciculations, and mild bilateral lower limb atrophy]
easing_factors: Rest, gentle limb massage, warm compresses, occasional over-the-counter acetaminophen for cramping.
past_history: History of mild hypertension, well controlled; no previous musculoskeletal or neurological complaints.
medical_history: No significant comorbidities aside from hypertension.
medications: Amlodipine 5mg once daily for hypertension; has been trialed on baclofen 5mg at bedtime for muscle cramps with partial relief.
personal_history: Lives with wife and two teenage children. Previously active, enjoys hiking and playing recreational tennis (has stopped due to weakness). Non-smoker, occasional alcohol. Reports mild anxiety regarding the impact of his diagnosis on work and family responsibilities.
imaging: MRI brain and cervical spine unremarkable; nerve conduction studies and EMG consistent with diffuse motor neuron involvement without sensory deficits.
